pros: -The hospital is a community hospital, run by comity elected by the city of Kirkland, WA -RN resident program is great, it's a year-long and they really make sure you feel comfortable before taking patients on your own -Nurse educators are amazing and great resources -Unit managers care a lot and want to see you succeed -Culture is pretty solid, we all want to see each other do well -Union is strong -Facility is beautiful, with private rooms for patients -Break rooms are nice -Incentive pay is offered frequently -Very welcoming to travelers -A "code lavender" was created that you could call if you as a staff member required emotional support after a challenging event
cons: -Lower pay than other hospitals on the east side, and far less than nurses working in Seattle -New residents sign a contract for 1 year on the floor they're hired on and 1 additional year at the hospital or pay a fine -Staffing ratios are 1:5 on days and 1:6 on nights -Holiday pay is only for 8 hours of your shift that occur within the holiday (because we previously had 8-hour shifts and after we moved to 12s it was never changed) -Upper management is out of touch with the day-to-day issues staff face -Staffing is poor, we're constantly being asked to pick up -Unit managers are expected to do so much that they become burnt out quickly -Lots of safety issues with aggressive/ abusive patients (mostly in ED and on 8 Silver) -No panic buttons in rooms -No dedicated behavioral health unit -One psychiatrist for the entire hospital that only works day shift

job_title: Certified Medical Assistant (CMA) in Kirkland, WA
pros: - Great Patients -Free parking
cons: My experience working for Evergreen was disappointing. I was hired on when there was a change in Management. Unfortunately, this individual was not cut out for the job. There was preferential treatment, lack of leadership, I witnessed bullying, and she was easily influenced by her peers.

pros: They take a chance on new coders.
cons: Micromanagement is a way of life for the department. The "culture" of the organization is: Unless you are in direct patient care, you are worthless. Expect to be "thrown under the bus" at the drop of a hat by management. They bend over backwards to make providers happy, even using questionable reimbursement policies when a surgeon throws a temper tantrum. HR will act as if they care, but in the end, they are there only to protect leadership, and leadership is there to protect the bottom line. Expect to work "optional" massive over time, and to have your PTO denied. Or approved, but you'll be expected to take along a personal laptop and clock in at least some of the time. Productivity standards are vague, but you will be put on probation for not meeting them. Training is next to nothing, yet you will get in trouble for not knowing the workflows well enough.

pros: Flexible environment. PTO, very nice insurance (only need to work 20 hr/week to receive full medical benefits)
cons: Salary was relatively low for amount of work needed.

pros:
Been at Evergreen almost 15 years. 
We celebrate many employees on their benchmark work anniversaries of 20, 25, 30, 35 and even 40 years!!!
Our leadership team truly cares about the community and its employees.
It is great to work for an independent health system when so many others are being consolidated and "corporate".
Benefits are incredible and PTO is generous for long-term employees.
Family atmosphere....people really do care.
cons:
No merit-based pay. Everyone gets the same raise whether you excel in your role or are skating by.
For more work and projects than resources. 
Work-life balance can be a struggle and there is an "always on" mentality from middle leadership.
Some office locations are deteriorating and are not appealing to attracting new talent.
Management doesn't follow the leadership tenants when it comes to modeling good coaching and showing a good work-life balance.

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant in Kirkland, WA
pros: The facility and equipment is beautiful and state-of-the-art. I worked in almost every unit of the hospital via rotations and they are constantly updating the units. Management is generally very nice, but they will always have a top-down approach. I transferred units twice in my 4.5 years here and my original hiring managers were wonderful, but they will always give preference to RNs over CNAs, regardless of situation.
cons: Unfortunately over the last 3 years management in FMC has become very cold toward the CNAs (not myself personally, just the group as a whole). Not sure why because we work our butts off to support the other staff, especially the RNs. Great place to work if you are an RN or aspiring to be. Otherwise, you are the bottom of the totem pole and they will treat you as such.

review_title: Red flagged onboarding leads to immediate offboard
job_title: Profee Coder I in Kirkland, WA
pros:
Possible Remote work
Saw potential in employees
cons: Disfunction and miscommunication from the start. HR refused to supply offer letter in writing. Benefits were poor and then HR skips out on new employee orientation of 85 people. No personal touch and lack of respect for employees. Forced to sign a legal document about following policies/procedures that weren't allowed to read before signing. Supervisor and manager argued repeatedly during interview. Antiquated DOS systems. So many red flags.

review_title: Good - until you hit the ceiling
pros: I have had a positive experience in almost all of the teams I have helped to support and have found it fairly easy to move up the ladder from starting out in healthcare as an appointment scheduler to an administrative assistant. A lot of the people within EvergreenHealth are supportive and kind and want to see you succeed.
cons: Since I have been an administrative assistant, a position I have held at EvergreenHealth for 5 years, I have applied to other jobs within the organization to further my career in healthcare, and have remained stuck in the administrative assistant role. It seems no matter how many times I interview, for even an administrative coordinator position (not shooting for the stars), I can't move further than where I'm at currently. The other issue I have is that EvergreenHealth pays less money to their employees than other healthcare organizations in the area for the same positions (anywhere from $2-$5 less an hour, depending on the position) and they only give raises based on cost of living, not based on how hard you work or if you've met your yearly goals. I would rather not get a raise every year, but feel like I deserved it when I did get one and have it be substantial. Not these insulting 10 cents every year that they give for "inflation". News flash EvergreenHealth, inflation rises by at least 3% every year! Last, but not least, my latest job here has had a BAD case of job creep. Since getting the position I have had more and more projects and tasks added onto my plate without alleviation from the ones I had to do already and without getting compensated for all of my extra work. If you do decide to work here, which it isn't a terrible place to work, just be sure to keep your wits about you and make sure you stop people from adding too much onto your plate. One of their favorite things to say is "How can we be more L.E.A.N.?"

pros: The staff here is very good, caring and nice people. The pay is good with pretty good benefits. Unit manager is good and tries his best.
cons: Often short staff, we work very hard, older equipment. Senior management not honest and look to work hospital like an HCA model.

pros: I've been a coder here for five years.  I work from home, but I still feel very involved with the organization and my input is valued.  Every time I have brought up an issue it is taken seriously and I get the help I need from my manager, my manager's boss, and even the director of the agency.  There are meetings set up, teams pulled together and we figure out how to resolve issues.  I have been pulled in to several LEAN projects because they get all of the stakeholders together to design new processes and procedures.  The pay is above market.  I get two raises a year and a retention bonus every year since ICD-10.  They are looking into getting a new electronic record system and they actually asked me what the coders need to be able to do our jobs.  Usually, they only consider the clinical and billing side of things.  I love my job.  They are very receptive to coders learning different types of coding so we don't get to bored
cons: My boss does not micromanage, which is great, except when there is an employee who doesn't pull their weight.  I don't think my department has ever been audited(we are a specialized coding group and my boss doesn't know a lot about it).  Luckily, my team is pretty good at accepting feedback and we check up on each other.

review_title: I was excited at first, but now it’s disappointing
pros: The patient population is nice. There are some really amazing doctors what work here. The benefits are decent.
cons: Management will tear you down in a heartbeat. God forbid a big life event happens and you need to get some time off to attend to such event- I was yelled at my first week on the job because of something like this. The pay is not worth the harassment from management yelling at you and your coworkers in front of patients. This hospital really needs to take a good hard look at some of their supervisors and managers that are over a certain age, because we are working our butts off, but it’s never enough. Our supervisor is constantly belittling us, all while she sits in the break room and does nothing. Please Evergreen, take a look at your management because your managers and supervisors will be the reason all the younger nurses leave. Also, the work-life balance is horrible here, plus the pay is less than fair. Give us accrued sick time, not EIB.

review_title: MSW Case Manager for Hospice in the Home and Community
job_title: Hospice Social Worker In Community in Kirkland, WA
pros:
respect and autonomy
great co workers
caring supervisors
cons:
BIggest con is NO OVERTIME FOR MSWs, despite typical 12 hour days. RNs get hourly, we do not. THere is also no written policy or plan for pay raises. The HR and management are fumbling and mumbling about it, and nothing gets changed. This is truly demoralizing.. and we work our personal lives to the bone, even those of us with good boundaries; the hospice patients and families need help-- we have to help. 

Way Inconsistant with caseloads.. when you get busy, you do not always get help, and the patients suffer and the staff (MSWs and RNs) get burned out and overworked. The scheduling department gets uppity if you ask for too much help, and often we are expected to suck it up and just do a good job.

pros: Loved my colleagues & patients. This organization is really great about team work.  Low staff turnover as most employees were happy here.  Fair wages & strong nursing union contract.   Huge focus on patient safety.  I would personally  stay there if I needed a hospital stay.
cons: The company systematically forces the older (and higher earning) nurses out.  If you are making over $100k/year you may be the target. Here come the disciplinary reports & patient complaints.  The manager literally followed one of my coworkers around & interviewed patients to find something he could be fired for.  It's cheaper to hire a new RN grad even though she/he has no experience & is certainly less safe.  I was harassed by my manager when if I was occasionally 5 min late for work even though patients loved me & I could handle a really heavy/complex patient load.

review_title: Great Place to Work BUT Don't Get Hurt They DON'T Care
pros: Opportunity to move within company - education - health benefits
cons: Expectation of workload exceeds what is safe and realistic. Staffing should be based on patient acuity vs patient numbers. Especially since you do not provide adequate care for injured employees. Pay is completely tenure based, not based on performance which breeds mediocrity. Example: there is an employee that has been caught  stealing twice; once from a fellow staff member and once from a patient. That employee still works in the same position.

job_title: Senior Systems Analyst in Kirkland, WA
pros: Very friendly and kind people to work with. Free parking. Employee activities to help you feel a part of the organization.
cons: I was in a technical role and my functional counterparts are underpaid and seem to resent those of us in IT who are paid closer to our market value. The result is IT is expected to do more than a typical IT folks would be ask to do.

review_title: A public district hospital that ignores it's mission.
pros: Dedicated co-workers.  Pretty hospital campus. Very good cafateria choices.  Many capital improvement projects.
cons: Evergreen is an institution rife with hypocricy and mismanagement.  It's stated mission is to "advance the health of the community it serves", yet over the past five years it has terminated myriad public health contracts with King County that have provided life saving  services to aging, disabled  and low income populations.  It also ranks dead last among area public district hospitals in the percentage of charity care to total revenue that it provides to the community.

pros: The employees are compassionate and considerate people, putting the care of their patients first.  They are great to work with.  Management tries hard, even though they do not always succeed in making an employee friendly workplace or building the best teams possible.  The Union is very supportive.
cons: Little opportunity for growth during this economic downturn.  And when making internal applictions for jobs, very little and untimely communication from HR.  Layoffs were not handled in the best way possible, even though management tried.

review_title: A Good Hospital that could be Great!
pros: Beautiful modern facility with plenty of money from community tax base support and wealthy benefactors.  Typically has the best equipment available for diagnostics and patient care.  Patient rooms are modern and up to date. Their pay scale is the best around. Voluntary Union not required to be a member.
cons:
The managers are not good with people and fail to protect their employees from patients who are letigious.
Bad morale between employees and Dr's they interact with.  Dr's are forceful and disrepectful to staff.  managers do not support the staff.

review_title: A little listening would go a long way in the Lab
pros:
Some wonderful people, fairly high level of care and cleanliness. 
Okay pay. 
Great directors. 
Can learn a lot about the different departments easily and quickly.
Some front runner technology and techniques.
cons:
Middle management is a poor. Act like bosses not leaders. 
Won't get rid of the problem people despite documented harassment and hostility. 
Manipulation is rampant. 
Gossiping is common. As always at work, don't talk about personal stuff unless you want everybody to know.

job_title: Clinical Laboratory Assistant in Kirkland, WA
pros: Love the staff and patients; beautiful facility that is frequently getting updates. There is a great selection for specialty care.
cons: Management is very disorganized. They do not seem to listen to feedback from support staff  on much needed process improvements. Upper management seems to turn a blind eye to issues below them. Support areas for patient care are chronically understaffed.

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Kirkland, WA
pros: Great providers and equal level co workers
cons: Business profits  gets in the way of patient care

pros: The pay is great $32.00 an hour. they love hiring RN's . You get 20 days of orientation and the evening nurses love working with newbies
cons: They always over staff I see people get sent home. The woman who does the scheduling have her favorites. I said before that the evening nurses like to work with the newbies the day shift nurses not so nice. I was new out of school and some of the nurses were not very nice.

review_title: Loved my job, upper management does not care about staff
pros: Loved working with patients--it's why I'm in the medical field
cons: Clinic management was mixed. Upper management added a great deal of uneccessary paperwork and rigid organization in order to "simplify." It didn't simplify. It frustrated.  When anything bad happens, don't expect upper management to have your back even if all of your peers do.

job_title: Clinic & Billing Manager in Kirkland, WA
pros: The physicians were amazing and I love that we wanted to care for patients in the same way. To make them feel like friends and family and not just part of another Healthcare system.
cons: New management took over in 2015 and wanted to bring in their own team instead of using the existing team so many people quit or transferred.

pros: Tremendous nursing talent/excellent co-workers, great commute if you live on the Eastside
cons: Nepotism/managers coddling their friends, lack of response to excessive absenteeism, driving low morale, lack of meaningful engagement of staff members, frequent and excessive policy changes, cramped/loud work place, top heavy with management, virtually zero growth opportunity

review_title: Has so much potential to be a great place to work but it's not.
pros: Beautiful facility and artwork. Free parking. Some really good nurses who are excellent at their job. Beautiful patient rooms. Decent cafeteria.
cons: Chronically understaffed. Management values cutting costs over safety of staff. Outdated equipment. Low pay scales compared to comparable other hospitals.

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Redmond, WA
pros: Great pay and Benefits, wonderful Co-Workers, great facility. Staffing Ratios are very typical. Patients are nice. Direct managers are easy to work with.
cons: Difficult in my department to get time off. They need better plans for sick calls. We are frequently short on staff. Staff education could be better in terms of making it easier for staff to take advantage of educational opportunities.

pros:
Beautiful
Big
hard working environmental staff that cleans and maintains
Dedicated Volunteers
cons:
No accountability of Administration and Management this hospital has a problem with equality and fairness in there hiring practices.  They care more about their bottom line than those who are actually the face of the hospital.
Rude Nursing Staff
Overworked staff
They do not up hold their cor values
Do not keep their promises

review_title: Uncertainty for years, culminating in layoff.
job_title: Case Manager II in Kirkland, WA
pros: Co workers are the best. The organization is providing severance.
cons: Despite years of being reassured that we were an essential and valued part of the organization the team I work(ed) for have been told we're being eliminated. Ours is the latest in a series of programs that have been cut.

pros: Flexible hours and decent pay for a relatively easy job. Benefits are hard to beat, and the staff are usually very friendly.
cons: Management is somewhat disorganized, push overtime on their employees constantly due to a lack of organization, and overall don't seem very empathetic towards their employee's needs.

pros: Positive, caring  and respectful cultural.  Patient and family focused.  Staff care about one another.  Leadership demonstrates the organization's values, they are approachable and strive to communicate and engage with staff.  Evident by CEO Town Hall Meeting's.  CEO is open, honest and willing to answer any questions that are asked.
cons: While growth is positive, it is sometimes challenging to keep up with the rapid pace of the organization.

pros: The benefit package is very good.  Management was not looking over your shoulder.  Could self-manage as a group.  Back in the 90s it was a great place to work.
cons: No reward or recognition for a job well done.  Upper management makes decisions of great impact without consulting the workers actually doing the job.

review_title: Low Salary, High Level Peple Getting Fired
pros: Some people are really dedicated.
cons:
HR has a tendency to propose low salaries.  I turned down a job offer from them because the salary was very low compared to other offers.  

HR was rude and unhelpful except for Spencer. I'm glad to be gone.

Their CFO is leaving and a Vice President of Primary Care is leaving.  Some people who still work there say layoffs might happen this year.

pros: They place high value on patient safety and health management. They try to make the best decisions they can for the community, employees, and patients.
cons: Suffers from exponential rapid growth. Leadership is very incestuous with a lot of entanglements and works like a good ol' boys club. Everyone has to drink the same Kool-Aid or move on, so not very progressive. They struggle to maintain a small town feel although the entire area is no longer small-town

pros: They have union for techs too. Pay is better than the rival hospital I used to work. Parking is easy and free.
cons: Traffic on 405 can be bad. Their new hire training was not so great. I had 6+ yrs hospital experience so it didn't affect me but they didn't teach us how their equipments work before the floor orientation so i had to figure them out on the floor.

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse (LPN) in Kirkland, WA
pros:
Colleagues are fantastic
patients are often kind and willing participants in care.
benefits are pretty good.
cons:
Upper management is primarily comprised of upper middle class white folks who have no idea how to foster a culture of diversity or equity within their organization.
HR exists to protect the organization and not the employee.
Raises are market based, not merit based.

job_title: Home Health Caregiver in Alvin, TX
pros: I enjoyed the wonderful group of employees and the positive work environment. I have never had an issue with this company, these women are awesome!
cons: The only downside in my opinion would be the lack of effort the business gave in finding dedicated caregivers. I got my job over the phone, the same day I called and showed interest. An interview would have been more professional.

pros: Good pay, great people. Benefits were very generous and affordable. Good benefit choices were made available.
cons: Meeting heavy environment. New CEO brought a change of all numbers and not about the employees any longer. Directors were not held accountable for mistreatment of HR employees.

review_title: A good place to work, no advancement opportunities
pros: Great benefits, and ample PTO.
cons: HIM department not overly recognized or respected. Considered "paper pushers." You're doing the same mundane tasks everyday with no new challenges or duties. Kind of feel like a robot. A little cliquey with the teams/roles you work in. If you like cubicles you'll be just fine here.

pros: Lovely facility.   Some very skilled providers. Staff kind to patients. Good hospital; many specialty clinics. Good initial general hospital  orientation.
cons: Over emphasis on "the bottom line."   A lot of insidious, passive aggressive (and not-so-passive)  backstabbing among employees at all levels.   There is  clear favoritism and nepotism among select employees.   Constructive feedback is  rare.  Discrimination seen.

job_title: Medical Laboratory Scientist in Kirkland, WA
pros: EHMC is a nice facility and in general the people in the lab are pleasant.
cons: Poor management & disorganized. You won't get great experience as a Med Tech here. Limited testing and critical thinking skills are discouraged.

review_title: Accepting a position in the HR Dept was the biggest mistake of my professional career
pros: Free parking, nice campus, decent coffee shops, mediocre benefits
cons: I observed unethical actions within the department, including violations of HIPAA, FMLA, and FLSA. I witnessed discrimination against protected classes of people.  I experienced ongoing and inappropriate commentary about my physical appearance and personal life.  I reported all of the above instances to my manager but nothing was done to improve the work environment.

review_title: It's just "OK" and starting to decline given the economy/leadership...
pros: Nice location, beautiful hospital, free parking.
cons: No room for growth, everything is black and white

review_title: Management is fair and staff people committed to their work
pros: Small enough that there's a lot of collaboration among medical staff, high standards for patient care
cons: Probably because the stakes are so high with patient care, any work has to pass lots of levels of approval before it's complete.

review_title: Questionable management - on third boss in one year.
pros: Health benefits, some good managers.
cons: Pay is completely tenure based, not based on performance which breeds mediocity. Mgmt talks about transparency, but it doesn't really exist.

pros: Have had a high quality of care with outstanding employees who have been there for 20 years.
cons: Pressures to make a cost effective product has brought about less flexibility and more less expensive and less experienced  employees.

review_title: Very bad experience with management ethics.
pros: I was at least a Clean workplace.
cons:
As another reviewer stated:
"Watch out. Leadership is quite incompetent and will never take blame on initiatives that they were responsible for."
I experienced this first hand, in fact, It is my opinion that I was hired with the underlying intent to take the blame for a previous project gone bad. I my opinion this was one of the worst ethics issues I have ever personally encountered.You have been warned!

job_title: Nationally Certified Medical Assistant in Kirkland, WA
pros: Love the culture here at EvergreenHealth. I was hired December 2019 and was impressed with the onboarding process. Had the opportunity to sit with the CEO who chatted with us during Christmas luncheon. I loved how he shared his experiences with us sat with us. People here really have a positive attitude.
cons:
Zero float support for ambulatory clinic
Compensation

pros: I enjoy working at Evergreen as an Occupational Therapist for the past several years. The other therapists are team oriented. You can take advantage of opportunities to grow by teaching, sitting on hospital wide committees and train and provide coverage on other units. One other advantage, parking is free.
cons: Weekend shifts are shared among staff.

review_title: One of the better hospitals to work at.
pros: Being a apart of the healthcare world. It's a very clean. Most departments works well with other departments. Never a dull moment.
cons: Benefits are costly for family of three or more. Lack of choice of benefits, having to request time off dates turned in twice a year.

pros: Good place to work. Advance opportunities only in nursing or if you are not colored
cons: Zero advancement in careers other than nursing. There will be growth opportunities for you if you are white.

review_title: Great organization, great benefits, though some challenges with department leadership
pros: Wonderful organization to work for with amazing health benefits.  Great reputation within the community.  Great staff and volunteers
cons: Some challenges with leadership at the department level.  Had a difficult time dealing with some issues and not fully supported by HR.

pros: Strong team work, good management, commitment to patient care
cons:
Limitation of hours that can be worked, that is, full time or 7/7 type schedule
Management sometimes confused
Crisis mode type messaging

review_title: Awesome work experience at Evergreen Hospital Medical Center
pros: Very nice, helpful and knowledgable staff, passionate about nursing.
cons: Most of the times census low in certain depts.

pros: Many hard-working people working there. I enjoyed my co-workers for the best part.
cons: Poor management- absent, clueless, and non-caring. Job duties changed nearly every week.

pros: Good employees at staff levels.
cons: Management promotes personnel who are malleable but, not those who are looking out for the staff members. HR lives in another world.

pros:
great culture and teamwork with use of Pod system to really give great care to your patients
Great support of patients and therapists by management
Paid for your time not by visit in home health
cons: Paperwork on Start of Care can be excessive

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Montpelier, OH
pros: Caring nurses and excellent management team. Environment is like being home it is place of going the extra mile to get things done, and to make our residents well and happy.
cons: There are no cons only positive outlooks for the future.

job_title: Medical Customer Service Representative in Seattle, WA
pros: Great employee benefits and you get to spend every day taking care of clients. Clean facilities and room for advancement. Good relationships between upper management and all workers.
cons: None that I can think of.

pros: Great organization. Have worked here 5 years and find the culture to be very supportive and employee friendly. Best place I've worked.
cons: 405 traffic coming to and from the hospital can be heavy at times

review_title: Health care system with growing pains but overall good experience as an employee.
pros: Updated facilities, hospital in safe area, modern dining facilities, ethnically diverse staff
cons: Leadership team focused on expansion and losing focus on quality care and adequate/safe staffing levels.

pros: Nice coworkers and nice manager in my department.  Overall pay and benefit packages are good!
cons:
Orientation poor. Tuition reimbursement poor unless you belong to union.
Software out of date.

job_title: Clinical Informatics RN in Kirkland, WA
pros: Conviently located with free parking, Room for growth/advancement
cons: smaller organization, political at times, unable to remain clinical if in a salaried position.

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse Charge Nurse in Gastonia, NC
pros: Rehab setting  allowed a nurse to utilize skills and nursing judgement in order  to assist and aide patients.
cons: Facility closed and staff were laid off and had to look for further employment.

job_title: Front Desk Receptionist in Kirkland, WA
pros: Agency is good at enabling staff to do their jobs well
cons: They don't like to help difficult patients and you get in terrible if you try.

review_title: Extremely dissatisfying and mismanged. Extremely pedagogic.
pros: Health benefits, renumeration are good. However, there are hard questions will remain.go figure.
cons: Terrible, terrible management. No one knows how to compete in the area and leadership cannot even give straigt answers to employees. Extremely based on tenure and if you ask questions, well... You are a threat.

review_title: Easy, kind employer who clings to process.
pros: Easy, Kind, Innovative, Treats Employees Very Well
cons: Too Attached to Process, Dislikes Change, Disinterested in the difficult patients, Impossible to contact HR

pros: Loved my co-workers and manager, good communication and support,  Great health benefits.
cons: Expectation of workload exceeded what seemed possible to do well.  Paperwork overload.

pros: Great company to work in. Positive team environment. I thoroughly enjoyed working on the trauma team and contributing to saving lives.
cons: I do not have any negative feedback.

pros: Excellent coworkers, and total compensation packages.  Progressive company always searching for new and innovative ways to perfect service to patients and Healthcare staff alike.
cons: Occasionally short staffed, but not often.

pros: The organization is very supportive of staff and does what they can to prevent burnout.
cons: It is a big organization and is not nimble.

job_title: Medical Records in Carson City, NV
pros: It was close to home.  Staff pretty much worked well together.
cons: Administrators were not consistant.  Constant changing of hands.

pros: Great place to work.  People there genuinely care about their jobs, the patients and each other.
cons: Too many and too frequent changes

pros: Rewards productivity. Lots of individual freedom.
cons: Administration is struggling how to manage a growing multispecialty group.

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Kirkland, WA
pros: Benefits and pay Are above average.
cons: Don't feel that my experience is valued.

pros:
The people at Evergreen are amazing. Everyone I interacted with is positive, helpful and wants others to succeed. 
Free parking!
cons: It's a great place to work.

pros: Great work environment. Sense of teamwork. Competitive pay.
cons: Long hours, but that is to be expected in an emergency room environment. I don't have anything negative to say.

pros: I like the atmosphere and the people I work with. I would recommend Evergreen Health as a good place for individuals to work.
cons: I can not think of any cons.

review_title: Decent place to work,  Low key.
pros: Pretty good starting pay and good benefits even for part time.
cons: The hours were not that good for the department I was working in.

pros: Good benes and nice people

pros: Lots of varied technology and very competent staff

pros: Promote agan workers. When you prove yourself
